 I actually play bass, but my friend has a Les Paul (not sure I spelled correctly) that I really like.....

Depends on what type of guitar you are speaking of. A good many of the better guitars out there are liked by almost a cult following for their individual qualities. Many electric guitars will have different sounds when played over the same equipment. 
 
 For my money:
 
 Electric: Fender Stratocaster
 Acoustic: Martin D-28
 Acoustic / Electric: Ovation Legend

You spelled it correctly. It is a "Les Paul." It is made by Gibson.
 
 Les Paul had his right elbow virtually destroyed in an auto accident. His doctors agreed to fix it in a position where he could play guitar. He was a great guitarist and had many hits back in my day. "Les Paul and Mary Ford" They were husband and wife.
 
 Les Paul was a pioneer of solid body electric guitars. He was great.

I have a Gretsch Country Gentleman circa 1968 that has been soaring in price the last few years. It's known for its mellowness, but I've always secretly wanted a Fender. There are so many songs that just seem perfect for the Stratocaster's bark, particularly its E A D strings. I also have a 1953 triple-aught Martin. Their sound is unmistakeable, such a sustained ring with each note. And an Ovation for everyday knockaround use which can't be beat. Also great is the way it can be amplified so easily, along with its playability.

My Axes
 Fender Stratocaster=Squire series
 Gibson SG
 Washburn Acoustic
 And a YaaaaMaaaaaHaaaaaa,Acoustic for just all around pickin and a grinin
I play a Takmine acoustic. Best guitar I've ever played.

I think pretty much any guitar is cool. I know that no one has responded to this in over a year, but I would like to mention that I myself play (the best, I have heard) air guitar. I would like for it to be real but the only one I can play is air guitar. emoticon_xclown

 Gibson Super-400
 Gibson ES-175
 Fender Telecaster (My Dad has mostly played Teles until '85)
 G&L ASAT and Broadcaster

 Get a J-Bass. Much more flexible than a P.
 
 And I'm used to wall-to-wall guitars. I work in a guitar store and can take down $5000 Fenders and have a blast. Or, I could if I was a guitarist. For now I fiddle with lefty-5-string basses when I'm actually a righty-4-string bassist.

In accoustics I like Larrivee. 
 
 I also recently played a Seagull (which are reasnably priced) that has a VERY nice sound. I think both happen to be made in Canada.

In keeping with the original question here What is the best guitar?? , let me offer what I think is an irrefutable answer:
 
 The one that suits you best...when considering a)sound eminating, b)ease of playing, c)comfort in holding and d)the way it looks...(I weight them 40, 30, 20, 10). Any that score over 70 prompt further consideration.
 
 I've had a $60 factory made, gut string, no frills el cleapo that sounded better than a $2000 Spanish guitar about the same size. I have a friend who makes his own banjos, collects guitars and he plays any one instrument exceptionally well. He can make a $60 guitar sound as fine a Strad violin being compared to a cheap chalk covered fiddle.

 I conditionally agree with that, the conditions being playing ability and instrument. Anyone who plays music and jams has been around 'the naturals', someone who can take the instrument you're playing, give it a few licks, adjust and it sounds like an entirely different instrument. And I've listened to musicians who think they're competent make the finest instruments ever produced sound like amateur hour. 
 
 It's very difficult if not impossible for anyone regardless of skill level to make a cheap banjo pick decent bluegrass like a medium priced or top of the line instrument as few of the low end pieces have tone rings.

Your absolutely right about the ability. That's why I said I can sometimes make a $60 guitar sound like one quite more expensive. As we know, $2000 is not a really high priced guitar. My super-talented friend came make any standard configuration guitar sound infinitely better than I. He also plays many pieces in non-standard tunings of a standard guitar. If there wasn't such a glut of musical talent available these days, he'd be a rich celebrity. I'm hoping he gets discovered before he gets alzheimers. The man know he knows some songs.
 
 

 It's very difficult if not impossible for anyone regardless of skill level to make a cheap banjo pick decent bluegrass like a medium priced or top of the line instrument as few of the low end pieces have tone rings.
Again, you're right. Banjos are sensitive to the tautness and quality of the skin, weight of the body and other things. I was limiting my claim to acoustical guitars.

 I have two Seagulls. A 12 and a 6. Sweet guitars and very reasonably priced for their value. The only problem with mine is they are satin finished and scratches take to them like a duck to water.

Good idea, but let me know when the spud truck gets exchanged for the Gulf stream V. I'd actually settle for a 111 or IV.
 
 One of my pleasures is listening to a natural player. Many players are great, but the naturals take music a step or more beyond great. I guess that's one of the reasons I have difficulty listening to most bar bands, regardless of the type of music, because it's normally easy to determine who someone is poorly trying to emulate. Most of the people I've known and know who lead bar bands tell me one of the secrets of sounding good (aside from a good, drunk audience) is covering up a weak player. 
 
 And you're right about there being some fantastic talent out there never to be discovered for recording purposes, many far better than some who do cut tracks. The road is a tough life if you're not a star. That's the reason many smart performers use professional studio musicians and state of the art technology for recording purposes. I can't count the number of performers I've heard live who sound like XXXX when compared to their studio recordings.

Good idea, but let me know when the spud truck gets exchanged for the Gulf stream V. I'd actually settle for a 111 or IV.
 
 One of my pleasures is listening to a natural player. Many players are great, but the naturals take music a step or more beyond great. I guess that's one of the reasons I have difficulty listening to most bar bands, regardless of the type of music, because it's normally easy to determine who someone is poorly trying to emulate. Most of the people I've known and know who lead bar bands tell me one of the secrets of sounding good (aside from a good, drunk audience) is covering up a weak player.
Michael Hedges was one of those natural players. You're right again about the cover-up. I've heard a great bass player make a crumby lead guitarist sound better with syncopation and sustained low notes. There are all kinds of tricks in the sound world. (I think a rising star in that bag of tricks is the use of double mikes.) 
 
 
 
 

 And you're right about there being some fantastic talent out there never to be discovered for recording purposes, many far better than some who do cut tracks. The road is a tough life if you're not a star. That's the reason many smart performers use professional studio musicians and state of the art technology for recording purposes. I can't count the number of performers I've heard live who sound like XXXX when compared to their studio recordings.
Right again. Lip-syncing is not an option for guitar players. A good sound system and soundman are crucial to live band sounds. This is one place where money sounds good...a lot of money sounds better. Then too, there are some venues where your own seating position is not optimized in the acoustic pattern of the hall. A talented player in a small venue, such as Leo Kottke and others prefer, is not as much at the mercy of the sound system as those bands who play packed stadiums and open field events. Make the listening parlor a bit smaller still and let the audience consist of polite listeners and you can even do away with the sound system, especially for pure instrumentals.
 
 I've been to several Bluegrass Pick-Ins where there were several groups jamming with only a few yards between clusters and you could hear whichever group you were near without much interference from adjacent groups. There's not much better sound than that of a butt-naked guitar!
 
 Damn, georged! We've got to talk music more often. I'm beginning to think you're an alright guy!emoticon_xhoho

 One of my favorite stories, retold from several instances, is from the days of single mikes with no mixing where performers had to be good on their own or die on stage. Leaders didn't use merely 'good' players. Each member of a five-piece group had to get right on that mike when they came out of backup for their part and many a slow mover was clobbered silly with a bass or guitar/fiddle/Jo neck as the performer swung out of the way as fast as he could because the next player was already rushing the mike leading into his bit. 
 
 One thing you've probably noticed about most bluegrass groups is that if they're using sound without a pro mixer, the Jo picker will be placed away from the other strings or that that tone ring is all you'll hear. And if the lead is guitar or mandolin, the Jo will always stay very soft. Leave them all flat-out natural and I can't keep my foot still.

Check out some of my sound gear guys....
 
 Main amps
 
 http://media.zzounds.com/media/fit,325by400/quality,85/brand,zzounds/P_Series_Amplifiers_Stacke-18256966b48baa081fd108b7b880a1e0.jpg
 
 Sub amps
 
 http://www.pssl.com/images/products/P0046553B.jpg
 
 Subs
 
 http://www.musiciansbuy.com/mmMBCOM/Images/yamaha_CW218V_dw.jpg
 
 Mains
 
 http://www.musiciansbuy.com/mmMBCOM/Images/YAMAHA_C215V_dw.jpg
 
 Monitors
 
 http://www.musiciansbuy.com/mmMBCOM/Images/jbl_srx712m_dw.jpg
 
 Monitor amp
 
 http://media.zzounds.com/media/fit,325by400/quality,85/brand,zzounds/AmpCE2000-e743180ac62c42efc72b3a74a6005fa1.jpg
 
 This basically my personal system I truck around with me. My sound reinforcement company however, uses full line self powered Mackie products.
 
 All of my boards are Mackies. My effect racks vary but have a lot of DBX compressors, Lexicon processors, and Barringer eq's and whatever else I could get a good deal on.

One of my favorite stories, retold from several instances, is from the days of single mikes with no mixing where performers had to be good on their own or die on stage. Leaders didn't use merely 'good' players. Each member of a five-piece group had to get right on that mike when they came out of backup for their part and many a slow mover was clobbered silly with a bass or guitar/fiddle/Jo neck as the performer swung out of the way as fast as he could because the next player was already rushing the mike leading into his bit. 
 
 One thing you've probably noticed about most bluegrass groups is that if they're using sound without a pro mixer, the Jo picker will be placed away from the other strings or that that tone ring is all you'll hear. And if the lead is guitar or mandolin, the Jo will always stay very soft. Leave them all flat-out natural and I can't keep my foot still.
The double mikes I'm talking about are pairs of mikes just inches apart in front of each singer in a group. Sony has just come out with an $800 miniature double mike digital recorder that fits in your pocket. The mikes are sensitive to different frequencies and combined, their signals more truly represent the actual recorded sound with greater sensitivity on both ends of the frequency spectrum. On the mini model, the mikes are nearly touching each other but they are in separate holders.
 
 There was a group on Austin City Limits several weeks back using double mikes about 4 inches apart with the singers "lipped up" to the upper mike. I don't know that I can tell the difference despite a blindfold, but I've never been able to tell the differences between quality systems with slightly different %WOW either. Some of the differences are likely too subtle to discern without multiple playbacks and a truly trained ear.
